The Florida Supreme Court today overturned a lower court decision to toss three proposed constitutional amendments off the November sixth ballot
The ruling means voters can still vote on amendments seven nine and eleven
Amendments seven would provide State University benefits for children to first responders who die on the job and require a super majority vote before university board of trustees could raise fees
Amendment nine would ban oil drilling in state waters and ban vaping in the same indoor workplaces where smoking is now banned
And amendment eleven would remove language deemed obsolete from three current articles in the state constitution
Last month the lower court ruled these items should be struck from the ballot because they bundled different issues nearly six hundred thousand vote by mail ballots have already been returned
